bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, December 16, 1929

div1.p: [Laura Carter] writes to Russell concerning her planned completion of her father's unfinished history of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, December 16, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Miscl
Russell, F. F.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
December 16, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Your good letter of December 11th. was awaiting me here
last Saturday, after a two day stay in Baltimore with Mrs. Frost.
I had hoped that Dr. Frost would return from Canada before I left,
but when I found that he would not get back until the following Tuesday
I decided to come home and do my usual Sunday work with Miss Brown.

To return to your letter: Of course you “expected” the book
“to be completed this year”! We all did! Had my best friend--or
worst enemy!-- told me that it would overlap into 1930, I should have
felt equally incredulous and resentful. Since, however, you state
that your accounting system can, for the future, handle, in conjunction
with Dr. Frost, the funds needed for the completion of the book, the
fact that there no budget item for it in 1930 in no wise affects the
work. Miss Brown has been working on a volunteer basis since Novem-
ber 1, 1927, as I, myself, worked up to the time of Father's death, and
as I shall consider it a privelege to work again. I shall, of course,
remain in Washington, with trips to Baltimore whenever advisable, until
the completion of the book. Whether I can continue to remain here there-
after is a question, as, despite the generosity of the Foundation in
the matter of my salary, my income from Father's estate will be far less
than he had counted on for me. That, however, is beyond my present
plans and preoccupations: “The book's the thing!”--and the only thing--
that matters until it isncompleted to the last detail. In this con-
nection. I can uever adequately express my profound gratitude and appre-
